title: 110_hr236
content: The Act is titled the "North Bay Water Reuse Program Act of 2007" and amends the Reclamation Wastewater and Groundwater Study and Facilities Act to include the North Bay Water Reuse Program. The North Bay Water Reuse Program Act of 2007 defines eligible entities as member agencies of the North Bay Water Reuse Authority in the North San Pablo Bay watershed, including counties such as Marin, Napa, Solano, and Sonoma. Water reclamation and reuse projects in this area focus on various improvements like water quality, wastewater treatment, and groundwater recharge. The State of California is defined as 'State' in the North Bay Water Reuse Program Act of 2007. The Secretary can enter cooperative agreements with eligible entities for water reclamation and reuse facilities. Coordination with non-Federal entities is encouraged for design work and environmental evaluations. The North Bay Water Reuse Program involves phased projects with the Corps of Engineers in the San Pablo Bay Watershed. The first phase includes planning, design, and construction of main treatment and conveyance systems, while the second phase focuses on sub-regional distribution systems. Cost sharing is required for the cooperative agreement. The Federal share of the cost for the first phase of the North Bay Water Reuse Program project shall not exceed 25 percent. The non-Federal share can include in-kind services that contribute to the project, such as planning, design, construction costs, and land acquisition. The Secretary will not provide funds for the operation and maintenance of the water reclamation and reuse project facilities. This section does not affect State water law or interstate compacts related to water allocation. Authorization of appropriations is provided for the Federal share of the total cost of the project, amounting to $25,000,000 for the first phase. This does not impact State water law or interstate compacts related to water allocation. Authorization of $25,000,000 for the North Bay water reuse program.
